Here's the premise: The daughter is an up and coming molecular geneticist at Johns Hopkins.

What made you pick on this topic?

I was fascinated by the idea of having a play that would portray the clashing ideologies of legitimate - what is considered legitimate science, the scientific method, the western scientific method, and the conflict with a belief system that is categorically against that.
And I find it very interesting, most white people in the U.S.
are unaware of the melanin movement, which I think is indicative of our cultural apartheid, if you will.
But the melanin movement is a real movement with its adherence and its literature that's published.
It's purports to be—books - have books that have scientific basis.
They have their charts and so on, and they have conferences and talks, and it's across the nation.
And melanists also teach in school systems from the grammar school to the college level.
So it's a very - it's a real movement, it's a movement that is about 30 to 35 years old.
It began with - in the 60s where the hypothesis was raised as to whether racism - white racism was or could be biological.
And those ideas were raised and were written about and debated.
And from that grew a ideology, which believes that people who have more internal melanin - we all have melanin, internal and external, and we all have the same amount of melanin, actually.

But the belief in the melanin science world, or camp, is that people of color have more internal melanin than other people, and that having more melanin enhances you intelligence and your athletic ability and your sensitivity and so on and so forth.
So I was just fascinated.
If I could present - how could I present this, and, in a way that could be universalized?

Because I think we are all in a situation, world-wide, where we have science and technology, ideology, ideas, what is proven by way of experimentation, and the clash with belief systems, which are anti-evolution, for example, and all kinds of belief systems with very strong convictions.
And how do we all work with this?
How do we discuss this?
Can we discuss this?
So I was fascinated by that faith, if you will, faith and ideologies and passions all clashing, and so that's how the play began.
